title: Critical geographies of racial and spatial control
abstract:
This article works through a set of studies that link racial and spatial control in\ud
explaining mutations of state-sanctioned and extralegal racism in concrete\ud
geographical conjunctures in the contemporary world. Critical human geography\ud
is particularly well poised to contributing to a broader debate about how to\ud
research racial formations beyond ideology, through materiality, embodiment and\ud
spatiality. Barbed wire, concentration camps, prison booms, aerial bombing, and\ud
the War on Terror are examples of material and geographical formations that must\ud
be explained beyond attention to social construction. Indeed, these technologies\ud
of power demonstrate the strength of state-sanctioned racism in our time, and\ud
the importance for critical scholarship to write with various forms of suffering\ud
in the ruins of contemporary racism, if we are to be able to understand new\ud
forms of anti-racism in the making
